sp.p: I was of that belief, and therefore fearing such a matter, I kept secret from my son and thee, that which now I will tell thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thou shalt know, for now in a manner, I begin to have some trust in thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: At last then, you know what manner of man I am.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: This marriage, was not meant to have been made indeed.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, was it not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: No, but I feigned it of purpose, that I might thoroughly try you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, is it true sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: It is even so as I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: See, I could never perceive so much. O notable policy.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay but listen to me, as soon as I bade thee go hence in, this man met me in excellent good time.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus saith this softly to himself.out alas, are we not clean cast a way?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I show him all that thou toldst me erewhile.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And this like wise to himself.what is this I here?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I entreat him for his daughter, and with much a do I obtain her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Ha, what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I say it is excellently well done.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now is there no let or delay on this man's behalf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I will straight go hence to bid every thing be made ready, and so bring word hither again.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now Davus I pray thee, sith thou alone hast brought this marriage for me to pass:

sp.speaker: (Da.
sp.p: Yea truly, ay, and none else.)

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That thou wilt yet moreover labour my son's amendment.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: In deed I will do what I can.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thou mayst now well do it, especially while he is nettled at the heart.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, set your mind at rest.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Go to then, but where is he now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: It is marvel if he be not at home.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Simo departeth and Dauus stayeth still.I will go to him, and tell him my mind in the same sort, as I told it thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
I am a forlorn creature, what shall keep me but that I must go hence straight into the grinding house to prison? No prayer or entreaty will serve, I have now brought all out of frame: I have deceived my master: I have forced a marriage on my master's son: I was the cause that the marriage shall be made today, even quite unhoped for of theold man, and clean contrary to the mind of Pamphilus. See these goodly crafts of mine: had I not
busied myself, there had happened no harm at all:Dauus espieth Pamphilus coming. but lo yonder I see him himself, I am but a dead man: I would to God here were some place, where I might throw myself down headlong.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Pamphilus takes on very much, that by following the deceitful device of Davus, he made answer to his father that he would marry.

sp.p: Where is that same mischievous varlet, which hath clean undone me?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now lord have mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: And yet I confess, this that hath happened, is even good enough for me, when I would been so sottish, and so very a dolt, as to commit my whole estate and welfare unto a prating villain. Therefore I reap a just reward for my folly. But he shall never scape scotfree with it.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This he saith out of Pamphilus hearing.I am sure to been safe enough for ever hereafter, if I may but now avoid this mischief.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But what may I now say to my father? shall I now refuse marriage, and yet promised erewhile that I would marry? with what face dare I do that? I wot not what to do with myself.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus speaketh all this out of Pamphilus hearing.truly nor I neither, what to do with myself: yet this is it I am fully resolved upon, I will tell him that I shall presently find out some remedy, and so put of my punishment yet a little while.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now he sees me.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Come hither you honest man: how say you sirrah, see you not how I (Poor soul) am bestead by means of your devises?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But I will remedy it by and by.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Wilt thou remedy it?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes certainly master Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yes, even as thou didst of late.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay rather better, I hope.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O, should I credit thee vile hangman? canst thou recover a matter full of trouble, and passed all hope of help? Out alas, what a sure stay had I of thee, who this day, out of my greatest quietness, hast forced me into a marriage spite of my tooth? did I not tell thee it would come thus to pass?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You did so.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What then art thou worthy of?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Hanging. But yet suffer me a little to come to myself, I will straight way seek out some help.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Alas that I have not leisure to punish thee as I would: it is now time for me to see to myself, and not to be avenged of thee.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: This scene doth chiefly contain the angry speeches of Carinus against Pamphilus.

sp.p: Is this a thing credible, or worthy to be spoken of, that there should be somuch perverseness in any man, as to delight in evil, and to seek his own commodity, even by the discommodity of another? Is this kind of people to be trusted? Nay certainly, those are the very worst kind of people, who are somewhat shamefast in denying a request, but afterwards, when time requires performance of their promises, then of necessity, they bewray themselves and falter, and yet the matter itself drives them then to a flat denial: then is their speech void of all shame and honesty, as thus: who are you sir? What friend of mine are you? why should you desire my sweet heart? O sir, hear you me, I love you well, but myself better. Nevertheless, if you ask where is truth and trustiness of promise, they are never a whit ashamed. Now they are not a frayed to deny, whenas they ought to perform: and yet are they then afraid, when they should not. But what shall I do? Is it best that I go to him, to taunt and take him up for this injury? I shall give him shrewd words his fill: but one may say to me, thou shalt be never the near: yes very much: without doubt I shall anger every vain in his heart, and withal shall ease mine own mind.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Carinus, I have unawares (Without God help us) even clean cast away both you and myself.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yea, unawares: is it so indeed? Now at last you have got an excuse: tush, thou hast broken thy faith and promise.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why, what excuse now at last?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, wouldst thou yet again deceive me now, with those subtle speeches of thine?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with you now?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Marry after I had told you that I was in love with Philumena, forsooth it pleased you to like her well for yourself: woe is me woeful wretch, who esteemed the honesty of thy mind by mine own.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You mistake the matter.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why, and dost thou not think this yet a joy perfect enough for thee, unless thou mayst make a tame fool of me that am in love, and feed me with vain hope? well, take her to thee.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Should I take her? Alack, full little do you know, in how great troubles I am wrapped, unhappy man that I am: and what care and anguish, this my tormentor hath put me to, with his devises.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why, is that such a marvel? he takes ensample by you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Well, you would not say this, if you knew either me, or my love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I know you were at words with your father of late, and that is the matter he is now displeased with you, but yet he could not compel you to marry her today.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yea and by how much the more you are ignorant of my heaviness: this same marriage was not meant or intended for me, neither did any man motion, now at this time, to procure a wife for me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I wot well, you are compelled to it even of your own free will.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Abide, you wot not yet how the case stands.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes certainly, I wot full well that you will marry her.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why do you thus kill my heart? hear me what I shall say to you: he never ceased, pressing, persuading, and praying me so long, till at last he enforced me to say unto my father, that I would marry her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What man did this?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Davus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, Davus?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yea, he brought all out of square.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wherefore did he so?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I wot not in the world, without that God were highly offended with me, in that I followed his counsel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Davus, didst thou do this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ha, what sayest thou villain? Now I pray God give thee a mischievous end as thou hast deserved. Why I pray thee tell me, if all the enemies he hath in the world would have wished to force a marriage upon him, what other counsel could they have given him than this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, I am deceived, but not discouraged.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ironic.I know it well.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The matter came not well to pass this way, now we will take another course, unless you be of opinion, that because it had ill success at the first: that therefore this evil may not now be remedied at the last.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yes marry may it, for I verily believe if thou do bend thy whole endeavour unto it, thou wilt make for me two marriages of one.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Master Pamphilus, this I owe unto you of duty, as being your servant: even day and night to labours to my uttermost with might and main, and to hazard my life to do you good withal: it is your part, if ought hath happened otherwise than was looked for, to pardon me. Be it that my doings prosper not: why yet I do my true intent: or find you some better remedy yourself, and let not me either make or meddle withal.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: That is it I desire: set me again in the same state thou foundest me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But it must be done by and by.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas, but yet stay a little, Glyceries' door creaks.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: That is nothing to thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yet I would know.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What, still more staying?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, I will presently find you out a device for this.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Here Pamphilus makes promise unto Mysis that he will never forsake Glycerie: yea though he shall procure all men to be his enemies for it.

sp.p: Wheresoever your friend Pamphilus be, I will forthwith seek him out, and bring him with me: in the mean time (Dear heart) do not you vex yourself with thought.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Mysis?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Who is there? O master Pamphilus, you meet me in very good time.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What is the matter with thee?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: My mistress bade me pray you for god's sake, if you love her, that you will come to her, now out of hand. She saith that she longs much to see you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p:
Out alas, I am a forlorn man? This mischief begins now again a fresh: is it meet that both I and she (Silly souls) should be thus vexed and disquieted
through thy means? for doubtless that is the cause she now sends for me, having understood of the marriage I am towards.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Concerning which matter truly, full easily might we have been at quiet, if this knave had not busted himself.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go too, if he be not mad enough of himself, do thou prick him forward.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Truly forsooth, and even that is the cause that the woeful woman is in sorrow for.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Mysis I swear to thee by all the gods, that I will never forsake her, no not if I wist, I should have all men living mine enemies for it. I have desired this woman in my heart: she is fallen to my lot: we are alike in manners and condition: farewell they, that would set us two asunder. There shall none part her from me, but only death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am now come to myself.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: No not the answer of God Apollo can be truer than this. Marry I would fain (If it may been) that my father shall not think, that I withstood the going forward of this marriage: but if it may not been, then will I go the plain way to work, that he may think that I did withstand it. What manner of man do I seem?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Even as forlorn a creature as myself.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I seek for counsel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou art a valiant man.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Davus I know whereabout thou goest.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, certainly I will bring this to pass for you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: It is more than time it were done.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I have it but even now to do.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: That thou deceive not thyself, I have it for this man's behoof, and not for thine.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That is sufficient for me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Tell me I pray thee, what is that thou wilt do?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I fear me, this day will scant serve me to do my business: think not than, that I am now at leisure to discourse: therefore get ye both away hence, for ye do but trouble me.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I will go see Glycerie.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And what will you? whither away hence?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wilt thou have me say the truth?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay, now he begins to tell me some long tale.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why thou shameless man, is it not well for thee, that I gain thee one little day's respite, in that I do prolong his marriage?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Davus, yet notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That I may attain to marry her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: See a fool.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, look thou come hither to me, if so he thou mayst do any good in the matter.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: To what end shall I come? I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet if thou may do ought.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, go too, I will come.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If thou mayst do any thing, thou shalt find me at home.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now he speaketh to Mysis.Mysis do thou stay here a little for me, till I come forth again.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: For a thing that must needs be done.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Hie thee apace.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I tell thee, I will been here again by and by.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Daws brings the child before Simoes' door, to th'end to drive Chremes back from accomplishing the marriage. And this scene consists more in gesture, then in utterance.

sp.p: What, can one be sure of nothing in this world? O lord God, I still thought, that this Pamphilus was my mistress chiefest joy, as being her friend, her lover, her husband, and one ready to serve her turn in all assays. But now (Alack forlorn woman,) what grief takes she for his sake? without doubt there is more harm in this, than there was good in the other. But lo, Davus comes forth. Abide fellow, what is that, I pray thee? whither away carriest thou the child?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Mysis, now must I needs have thee show thy ready wit and cunning in this matter.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Where about goest thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Take this same child of me quickly, and lay it down before our door.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What I pray thee, on the bare ground?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Take thee some herbs of this altar, and straw under it.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: And why dost not thou do it thyself?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Because if perhaps I shall be driven to swear to my master, that I laid it not there: that then I
may swear with a safe conscience.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I perceive you. But yet tell me, I pray thee, how is it come upon thee to be so holy now of late?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go too, bestir thee, that thou mayest know further of my mind, what I will do. O good lord.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why, what now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The bride's father is come, and hath prevented me. Now I leave of my purpose which I first intended.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I wot not what thou sayest.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will now make as though I came this other way on the right hand: see that thou been ready to answer and uphold my talk, in every point as shall been needful.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I perceive not at all, what thou intendest to do. But if there been any thing that my help may stand you in stead, or that thou see further into the matter than I do: I will stay here, lest you should be hindered of any benefit by my default.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Chremes heareth that Glycerie hath a child by Pamphilus, and withal that she is a free born woman of Athens: by which means, he is quite withdrawn from the marriage.

sp.p: Now that I have made all things in a readiness for my daughter's marriage, I am come again that I may cause her to be sent for. But what have we here? In good faith it is a child: woman didst thou lay this same child here?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: She looks after Dauus.whether is this fellow gone?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, wilt thou not answer me?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Alack he is nowhere in sight, woe is me (Poor wench) the fellow is gone his ways, and left me here.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now Dauus comes a long.good lord of heaven, what hurlyburly is yonder at the market? how much people is there at strife? without it be that corn be at a high price, I wot not in the world what to make of it.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray you sirrah, why did you leave me here all alone?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How now, what tale is this of a rosted horse? Nay but hearest thou me Mysis, whose child is this? or who brought it hither?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Art thou well in thy wits, that askest me this question?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Whom then should I ask, seeing here is nobody else?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This he saith to himself. Chremes must be supposed to stand a loof listening unto all the talk between Dauus and Mysis, and yet not showing himself unto them, but upon occasion of their talk he oft-times utters speeches as to himself.I marvel whence it should be?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wilt thou not tell me what I ask?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Alas.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Come thy way hither on my right hand.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Thou ravest, didst not thou thyself? —

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Husht, be not so hard for thy ears as to speak one word more than I shall ask thee.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Thou railest.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Whence is this child? speak out aloud.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: From among you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, it is a wonder no doubt, if a whore play a shameless part.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He speaks this to himselfthis maid belongs to her of Andros for ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Do we seem such fit copesmates for you to mock and dally withal?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To himself.I came in time.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Bestir thee quickly, and take a way the child hence from the door. This, Dauus speaks in a lower voice, that Chremes may not hear him.abide still, see thou stir not a foot out of the place thou standst in.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray God a very vengeance light on thee, that so dost terrify me, poor wretch that I am.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Do I speak to thee or not?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And dost thou yet ask me what? I pray the whose child hast thou laid here? Tell me.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Dost not thou know?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This he speaketh softly unto her.let pass what I know, and tell me what I ask.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: It is yours among you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Which of us oweth it?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This he repeats aloud because Chremes may hear him.ha, what saidst thou? Is it Pamphilus' child?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why I pray thee and is it not?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To him self.I see I did well always to shun this same marriage.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O notable prank worthy of punishment.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What exclaiming makest thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why, did not I see this same child brought unto you yesterday in the evening?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: O thou brazen fast fellow.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus urgeth Mysis to prove plainly that the child is born of Glycerie, lest otherwise Chremes should imagine it to be a feigned matter, as Simo doth. Act. 3. Scen. 1.at least I saw gammer Canthara with her clothes tucked about her, carrying somewhat in her lap.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p:
In good faith yet I thank God with all my heart,
that there were some free women of the city, at my mistress deliverance.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Without doubt she knew not him, for whose cause she takes this matter in hand. If Chremes shall see this same child, laid here before the door, then will he not give his daughter in marriage: ah, in good sooth he will give her somuch the sooner.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Meaning by himself.but in good sooth he will not.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now be thou well assured of this, that if thou do not take away the child, I will by and by spurn it into the midst of the street, where I will trample thee also in the dirt.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: In good sadness fellow, thou art not well in thy wits.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: One deceitful device brings another to light: I hear now such whispering among them, that this same Glycerie is free born of Athens.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Chremes speaks still to himself.what is this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So as he shall be driven by law to marry her.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why I pray thee, and is she not free of this city indeed?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I see I was well nigh fallen into a shrewd sporting game unawares.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who talketh here? O Chremes, you come, in as good time as may be: hear me what I shall say.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I have heard every word already.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, have you heard all this talk?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I tell thee I hard all from the beginning.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I pray you and have you heard it in deed? fie, out upon these lewd pranks: now should this same quean be had hence into Bridewell. This same is the man thou dost mock: think not then, that thou mockest Davus.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Alas for me unhappy wench that I am: in good sooth, old father, I have told nothing but truth.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I know the whole matter already: but is Simo within.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: It seems that Dauus offereth to dally and play with Mysis, seeking thereby to please her: and she will not abide him.touch me not thou varlet. By God if I tell not all this unto Glicerie, [never credit me.]

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why thou foolish wench, thou perceivest not what is done.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What should I perceive?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This man is the bride's father: it might not otherwise be compassed, to make him understand these things that we would have him.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why then, thou shouldst have told me so before.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I pray thee now, and dost thou think but small difference between that, that one doth in good earnest, and that which is done for the nonce.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Crito coming from Andres to Athens, enquireth whether Glycerie have found out who be her parents or no: and understanding that she hath not yet found them, he is therewith much grieved, because that matter doth hinder his enjoying of the goods fallen unto him by Glyceries' death.

sp.p:
It was told me, that here in this street, dwelled Chrysis, who chose rather in this town to gather goods with dishonesty, than to lead an honest poor life, in her own country. By whose death, those same goods, by right of law, are come to me. But I see now of whom I may
inquire. God speed you.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray you whom do I see? Is not this Crito, cousin germane to Chrysis? it is even he.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: O Mysis, God save you.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: And you too good Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Alack for pity, and is Chrysis dead indeed?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Yea truly forsooth, we poor souls are undone by her death.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why, what do you? how goeth the world with you here, all well?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What we? Truly (As the proverb goeth) we do as we may, sith we may not as we would.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How fares Glycerie, hath she found out yet who be her parents here?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Would god she had.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why then, and hath she not yet? Than in an ill hour am I come hither. For in good faith if I had known this, I would never have set foot forward in this journey. For she hath ever been held and reputed for Chrysis own sister. She is in present possession of all that theother had. And now, for me a stranger to go follow suits and brabbles in law, how easy and profitable a matter were that for me here to do, even the examples of others do foreshow me. Besides that, I cannot but think, that she hath now some friend and defender, for she was of meetly good age and stature, when she went from us. I should be exclaimed upon to been a beggarly fogger, greedily hunting after heritage. And moreover, it were no reason to spoil her of that she hath.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: O gaffer Crito, in good sooth full well dost thou keep thy old wont still.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, sith I am come hither, bring me to her, that I may yet see her.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: With a very-good will.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will follow these, but I would not for any thing, that the old man should now see me.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Simo earnestly desireth to effect the marriage: Chremes on the other side utterly renounceth Pamphilus for his son in law, because he hath a child by Glycerie.

sp.p: Well neighbour Simo, you have now had trial enough and enough again, of my love and friendship towards you. I began to enter into danger far enough for you. Now at length cease your entreating: for while I bent myself to follow your fancy, I had well nigh cast away my daughter.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay rather (Neighbour Chremes) I most instantly request and beseech you, that you will now perform in deed, the good turn that ere while you promised me on your word.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: See how unreasonable you are, respecting your own desire: so you may bring to pass what you would have, you neither regard a mean in courtesy, nor yet consider what you request at my hands: for if you did, you would (Now at last) give over to surcharge me with your unreasonableness.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: With what unreasonableness?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Why, and do you ask me with what? marry sir, you enforced me thus far, that to a loose young man entangled
in love with a strange harlot, and utterly misliking marriage, I should give my daughter to wife, to be in daily discord, and uncertain state of wedlock, to th'end that with her travail, and trouble, I might heal your son's disease. You obtained this at my hands, and I went about it while there was any boot: now it boots not, you must therefore bear with me. They say, that same woman is free born of this city. She is delivered of a child. Seek to us no further.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I beseech you for god's sake, not to give your mind to credit those, whose greatest profit groweth by my son's lewdest living: all this, is but forged and framed for the nonce, by reason of this marriage: when the cause why they do this, is once taken away, than they will cease.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You are deceived, for I myself saw her maid chiding and brawling with Davus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I grant you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay but in right good earnest, whenas neither of them both was aware of my being there.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I believe it well, and that they would do so, Davus fortold me a pretty while since, but I wot not how, otherwise than I meant, I forgotten to tell you somuch.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Simo hearing by Davus, that there was one come, which affirmed Glycerie to be free born of Athens: in a great rage, causeth Davus to be had into prison fast bound. And herein, Terence doth lively express the usual manner both of an angry father, and also of an angry master.

sp.p: At my word, now (At length) set your heart at rest:

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Thus Simo and Chremes do talk betwixt themselves, and Dauus goeth on still in his speech.see where Davus is.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thus Simo and Chremes do talk betwixt themselves, and Dauus goeth on still in his speech.whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What through my help, and yonder stranger.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He speaketh out of Davus' hearing.what knavery is that?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I have not seen a meeter man, a more seasonable coming, nor a fitter time.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And so here likewise.whom doth this varlet prays thus?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now all is out of danger.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why do I linger to speak to him?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now at last he espieth Simo.my master is here, what shall I do.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O, all hail to you honest man.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now master, and master Chremes, all things be in a readiness within.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O it is trimly done of you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now send for him when you will.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Very well surely: that is the cause forsooth he is now absent: nay but answer me to this, what business hast thou there? That is in glyceries house

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who, I?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea, you sirrah.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I went in but even now.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: As though I asked how long ago it was.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Your son and I went in together.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why then, and is Pamphilus within? I am still vexed unhappy man that I am. Why thou hangman thou, didst not thou tell me that they are fallen at debate.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So they are.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What makes he there than?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This is spoken in derision.what think you that he is a doing? he is sure chiding with her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay but master Chremes, you shall hear me tell you of a notable strange matter: I wot not what old man is come yonder even now, but to look to, he is a substantial and wary man: if you saw his face, you would take him for a right honest man. In his countenance is sad gravity, and his words do sound of truth.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What tidings bringst thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nothing forsooth but what I heard him say.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And what saith he, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Marry that he knoweth Glycerie to be a free born woman of Athens.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Simo calls for him that whips the slaves.hola howh, Dromo, Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Dromo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why, hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: If thou speak one word more — Dromo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I beseech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What would you have sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Hoist up this knave on thy back, and carry him in as fast as thou canst.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Davus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Because I will have it so, take him away I say.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What have I done sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If you do find that I told you any lie, kill me forth right.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I will not here one word: I shall set thee in a beat by and by, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, notwithstanding I say nothing but troth?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He speaks to Dromo.yea nevertheless, sirrah see thou that he be kept fast fettered: and hearest thou me? bind his hands and feet together,He turns his speech to Dauus and Pamphilus. now sir go to: by God if I live this day to an end, I will teach thee and him both, what danger it is for the one of you to beguile his master, and for the other to deceive his father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Tush man, be not in so great a rage.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O Chremes, do you not pity me, to see what reverend regard my son hath towards me? and that I should take somuch travail for such a son? Well go to Pamphilus: come out here Pamphilus, is there no shame in thee?

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Simo sharply rebuketh his son: who confessing his fault, submitteth himself wholly unto his father's pleasure, Chremes endeavoureth to appease the extreme rage of Simo.

sp.p: Who calls me? O I am undone, it is my father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What sayest thou? thou errand —

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Fie, go to the matter, and cease your evil language.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea as though there could be any name too ill for this fellow. Now sirrah, do you say the same too? Is Glycerie free bone of this city?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: So it is reported.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: So it is reported? O wonderful impudence, doth he consider what he say, think you? is he any thing sorry for his misdeed? Nay but see, doth his colour any whit change, or show any sign of shamefastness? is it meet he should be so unruly, as that contrary to the custom of his countrymen, contrary to law, and contrary to the mind of his father, he do labour to have that same naughty pack, even to his utter infamy and reproach?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Woe is me, forlorn man that I am.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O Pamphilus, Pamphilus, dost thou now perceive that, and never before? Long since iwis, long since, when thou gavest thy mind so lewdly, as that by one mean or other thou must fulfil thy lust: lo, even that very first day, had this been truly said of thee. But what mean I? why do I vex and disquiet myself? why do I consume myself with care? why do I wear my old age, with sorrowing for his madness? is it, that I should suffer punishment for his faults? Nay rather, let him have her: and farewell he: let him live with her and spare not.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My good father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What my good father? as who should say, you have any need of this father: why, you have got you house, and wife, and children, and all maugre your father's heart. There be also those brought, which affirm that same quean to be free born of this city: well, you shall have the victory.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Father, may I speak a word or two?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What wilt thou say to me?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Simo, yet hear him.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I hear him Chremes? what should I hear him?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why man, yet give him leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Well go too, he may speak, I let him not.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p:
Father, I confess I love that same woman: and if that be an offence, I confess that also. I submit
myself into your hands father, lay upon me what charge you will: command me. Is it your pleasure I should marry a wife? will you have me forgo this woman? well, I will bear all as I may. Only this I beseech you, not to believe that this old man is come hither by my appointment. Give me leave to clear myself, and that I may bring the man here before your face.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That thou mayst bring him here?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Yea father, suffer. me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He craves but reason, give him leave.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Let me obtain this much at your hands.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I am content. Chremes, I yield to any thing, so that I find not myself to be deceived by this fellow.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Small punishment contents a father, for a great offence in his son.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: In this scene Crito of Athens meeteth both with Simo and Chremes, whereby the whole error of the comedy is laid open: for here, Glycerie is manifested to be the daughter of Chremes.

sp.p: Cease to pray me, any one of these respects, shall cause me to do it: as either for your own sake, or for that the matter is truth, or in respect that I wish well to Glycerie.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
What, is it Crito of Andros that I do see? Truly it is he indeed. Welcome Crito:
what make you at Athens, being here such a stranger?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: It is so fallen out. But is this Simo?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This same is he.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What, is it for me thou askest? why sirrah, dost thou say that Glycerie is free born of this city?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dost thou deny it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What, and art thou come so well provided indeed.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Askest thou why? shalt thou do this, and scape unpunished? dost thou toll here into thy snare, young men void of experience, and honestly brought up? Art thou he that feedest forth their minds with enticing and fair promising?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Abide, art thou well in thy wits?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And dost thou make marriages betwixt them and the harlots that they are in love withal?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: This to himself.alas I am undone, I fear me the stranger will have never a word to say.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Simo, if you knew this man thoroughly, you would not think so of him: this is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: May this fellow be an honest man? comes he this day so jump in the very time of this marriage: and could he come never before now? why Chremes, is this a man to been believed?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Were I not afeard of my father, I could tell him that which would satisfy him in this point well enough.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Ha fogging knave.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Crito bear with him, this is his fashion.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p:
Nay let him consider what he is: as for me, if he proceed to call me at his pleasure, he shall hear that, that shall been little to his liking. Do I let that same marriage? or do I ought at all pass
for it? He turns his speech to Simo.thou dost not bear thy grief patiently: for as touching what I spoke, whether it been true or false that you heard, may soon be known.

Here is recited the argument of the comedy.a certain man of Athens, a good while since, suffering shipwreck, was cast on shore at Andros, together with that same Glycerie, as than a little child. This man being then in need and necessity: by chance first arrived at the house of Chrysis father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now he begins a fable.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Suffer him to go on.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What, even so indeed? he interrupts me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Go on with your tale.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Moreover, he which received him into his house, was my cousin: there did I hear the man himself say, that he was of Athens: and in that house he died.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Would you know his name so quickly? Phania.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Out alas today.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In good sooth, I take it, his name was Phania. This I am well assured of, that he said he was aRhamnus was a famous village by Athens. And Rhamnusius, 〈◊〉 is a man of that village. Rhamnusian.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O the King of heaven.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yea Chremes, there were then many other in Andros, which hard him say the same.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Would to God it were no otherwise than I hope for. But tell me this Crito, what said he then as touching the girl? did he say that she was his daughter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Whose then?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: His brother's daughter.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Without doubt she is mine.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Listen to this gear Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What think you of this?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That same Phania was my brother.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I knew the man, and I wot well he was your brother.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He flying hence, for fear of the war, takes his way after me into Asia, and than he was afraid to leave her here behind him. Since which time, I never heard what became of him till now.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am well nigh beside myself, my mind is so whelmed, with fear, hope, Joy, and with wondering at so great, and so sudden good hap.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now in good faith, I am glad that by many proofs she is found to be your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father I believe it well.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But there remains yet one doubt, which sore troubles me.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You are well worthy to be hated for your peevish preciseness: you make a doubt where all is as plain as a pack staff.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What is that you doubt of?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Her name falls not out right.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Truly she had another name, when she was a child.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What name? Cannot you remember it Crito?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I am calling it to mind.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Shall I suffer this man's memory to be a hindrance unto my wished joy, whenas I may help myself in this point? no, I will not suffer it. Lo you hear Cremes, the name you seek for, is Passibula.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That same is she.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is it even she.

sp.speaker: Pamp.
sp.p: She hath told it me her own self a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Chremes, I ween you believe that we all rejoice at this.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yea so God me help, do I believe it.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father, what remains now to be done?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: The matter itself hath reconciled me a good while since.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O an excellent father. Chremes altereth nothing as touching my wife, but that I may still enjoy her, as I have done.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Marry and good cause why. Unless your father say otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Only, as touching the dowry.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea marry, that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pamphilus her dowry is five hundered pound.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I accept it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I will now hie me to my daughter, and you Crito, go with me: for I believe she never knew me.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And why do you not rather cause her to be brought hither to you?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You put us well in mind, I will presently cause Davus to go about that matter.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He cannot.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Marry because he hath a great matter of his own, which toucheth him nearer.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He lieth bound in prison.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father, then is he wrongfully bound.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Not so, I commanded it.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I beseech you, command that he be let loose.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Go to, be it so.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But make haste than.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I go in straight way.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O blissful and happy day that this is.

argument.head: The argument.
argument.p: Pamphilus declareth unto Davus, how that Glycerie is found to be free born of Athens, and that he shall marry her likewise Carinus showeth unto Pamphilus, that by his means, he also may obtain Philumena at Chremes hands. This scene brings another son in law to Chremes: lest that either Carinus should depart away sorrowful, or that Philumena should be left unprovided for.

sp.p: I I am come forth, to see what Pamphilus is a doing: but lo where he is.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Perhaps somebody would think that I scant believe this to be true, but I will have it to be true, as it is in deed. I suppose that therefore the life of the gods is everlasting, because pleasures do properly belong unto them: for mine own part, I am in heaven all ready, if so be it, no grief of mind do intermingle with this joy. But now what man should I most specially desire to meet withal, to whom I might show all that hath happened.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This to himself.what great joy is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Lo, I see Davus: there is no man living that I would fainer have: for I am sure that he, of all other, will unfeignedly rejoice at my joy and gladness.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Whereabout here, is Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Davus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: It is I.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O my master Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Thou wotst not what hath happened to me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Very true, but I wot well what hath happened to myself.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: And so do I too.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yea it came to pass after the common course of the world, that you knew of the evil that happened to me, sooner than I knew of the good that happened to you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: My sweet love Glycerie, hath found out who be her parents.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O happy chance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This he saith to himself.what is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Her father is a very special friend of ours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Chremes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You say well.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Neither is there any let or tarriance, but that I may marry her out of hand.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is spoken out of the hearing of Pamphilus.what, doth he not dream trow you, that which his mind ran upon being awake?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Now moreover Davus, as touching the child.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Tush let it alone, God doth specially provide for it above all other children.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Carinus is over heard by Pamphilus.I am a made man, if this be true: I will sure speak with him.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What man is there? O Carinus, you come to me, even as well as heart can wish.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is well.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What, have you heard the matter?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes every whit: go to, have some respect of me, now in the time of your prosperity: I know that Chremes is now yours altogether, and will do all that you will have him do.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I wot it full well: but it would be too long for us, to tarry and look for his coming forth:
Therefore follow me along this way: he is now within with Glicerie. Davus go thou thy way home: hie thee, go for company to bring her away hence. Why dost thou stand still? why goest thou not?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I am going.

This seems not to he spoken by any of the interlocutors, but by some other coming last on the stage.do not stay looking for their coming out: for she shall be betrothed within: and if any thing more remain to be done, it shall been dispatched within also.
Now clap hands, and rejoice.

note.p: Here is to be understood that as Pamphilus hath Glycerie to wife: even so Carinus likewise hath Philumena, the other daughter of Chremes.
